This '''individual''' was a [[wizardkind|wizard]] who, in [[1379]], partook in an [[1379 duelling contest|international duelling contest]] on [[Dartmoor]].<ref name="WBoS">{{WBS}}</ref>

The duelling was noted, by witnesses, to have been of a standard that few had ever seen before. As the contest progressed, only four contestants remained: this wizard, two other wizards, and an [[England|English]] witch, [[Elizabeth Smudgling]].<ref name="WBoS"/>

The [[First semi-finalist of the 1379 duelling contest|first semi-finalist]] was defeated by the [[Second semi-finalist of the 1379 duelling contest|second semi-finalist]], making this individual face the second wizard.

[[File:Duelling contest 1379 2.png|250px|thumb|left|The third semi-finalist faces the [[Second semi-finalist of the 1379 duelling contest|second semi-finalist]]]]
His opponent brought a great storm cloud down from the sky, drenching him in freezing-cold [[Water|rain]] and forcing him to evade bolts of lightning. He then got the idea to call a powerful cyclone, which not only blew away the storm, but also the [[Second semi-finalist of the 1379 duelling contest|second wizard]], the [[Judges of the 1379 duelling contest|judges]], most of the spectators and several trees.<ref name="WBoS" />

It took several hours for everyone to regroup. Frightened of what the third wizard might do for his encore, the [[Judges of the 1379 duelling contest|judges]] attempted to talk [[Elizabeth Smudgling]], the last remaining finalist, out of duelling him, telling her that it might be easier if they simply gave him the cup before anyone else got hurt, but she refused.<ref name="WBoS" />

[[File:1379 Third Vs Smudgling.png|250px|thumb|left|[[Elizabeth Smudgling]] disarms the third semi-finalist]]
[[Elizabeth Smudgling|Smudgling]] and the third wizard then went up against each other. On the count of three, the wizard began a [[Mountain-moving spell|long, complex incantation that would have caused a mountain to break out of the ground]] and fall upon Smudgling's head had he been given the opportunity to complete it. However, Smudgling beat him to the punch, quickly murmuring the incantation for the [[Disarming Charm]] and sending his wand flying out of his hand. She was awarded the title of "[[Supreme Dueller]]" and the Disarming Charm became one of the most useful spells in any dueller's repertoire.<ref name="WBoS" />

==Appearances==
*{{WBS}} {{1st}}

{{Quote|If Dean is listening, or if anyone has any knowledge of his whereabouts, his parents and sisters are desperate for news.|[[Lee Jordan]] appeals to listeners on ''[[Potterwatch]]''|Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows}}
This '''man''' was the [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] stepfather of [[Dean Thomas]].

==Biography==
He married [[Dean Thomas' mother|Dean's mother]] some time after she was abandoned by her [[Dean Thomas's father|first husband]]. They had several [[Dean Thomas's half-siblings|children]] together and lived happily in [[London]].<ref>[http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/extrastuff_view.cfm?id=2 Dean Thomas's background] at {{JKRS}}</ref>

After [[Cedric Diggory]] was murdered by [[Tom Riddle|Lord Voldemort]] in [[1995]], Dean consciously avoided telling his parents about the event, presumably because he did not want them to pull him out of [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry|Hogwarts]], although it also seemed likely the same murderer would be coming after their son as well, hence he did not wish to fill his parents with unneeded dread.<ref name="OOTP11">{{OOTP|B|11}}</ref>

When Dean was forced to go into hiding during the [[Second Wizarding War]], Mr Thomas and his wife did not know where he had gone, and feared the worst, so ''[[Potterwatch]]'' broadcasted a request urging anyone who was with Dean to order him to please contact his family.<ref name="DH22">{{DH|B|22}}</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*It may have been possible that Dean Thomas' story could have been partially inspired by the song "Colour Him Father" by an American group The Winstons, which tells of a young man respecting his stepfather who cares for him and several siblings. The stepfather married a war widow, as the narrator says his true father "was killed in the war", akin to Dean Thomas' father being killed by Voldemort.

{{Dialogue a-b-a|Tom|The usual, Hagrid?|Rubeus Hagrid|Can't, Tom, I'm on Hogwarts business.|Good Lord, is this — can this be —? Bless my soul. Harry Potter… what an honour. Welcome back, Mr Potter, welcome back.|Tom meeting [[Harry Potter]] in [[1991]]|Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone}}
'''Tom''' (fl. [[1938]]—[[1990s]]) was a [[Great Britain|British]] [[Wizardkind|wizard]], who was the landlord, innkeeper, and barman of the [[Leaky Cauldron]]. He was very friendly with many [[Wizardkind|wizards and witches]] that passed through the pub to get to [[Diagon Alley]].<ref name="PS5"/> He had run the Leaky Cauldron for a long time, and had had the pleasure of meeting [[Harry Potter]] and former [[Minister for Magic]] [[Cornelius Fudge]] on more than one occasion.<ref name="POA3"/> It is likely he had met other celebrities and political figures in the [[wizarding world]], such as [[Albus Dumbledore]], since his pub leads directly into Diagon Alley. He was very old by the time [[Harry Potter]] knew him, as he was mentioned by Dumbledore in the late 1930s to [[Tom Riddle]].<ref name="HBP13"/>

==Biography==
===Early life===
Tom was likely a pupil at [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]] and studied there from the age of eleven until he left, and eventually became barman/landlord of the [[Leaky Cauldron]] some time before [[1938]]. It is possible that Tom encountered [[Tom Riddle|Tom Marvolo Riddle]] (later to be known as Lord Voldemort) on his way to [[Diagon Alley]] for the first time, as [[Albus Dumbledore]] had told Tom Riddle to ask for him to get there. Riddle's profound distaste for his given name was, in part, due to it being so common, and meeting the landlord would not have negated this opinion in any way.<ref name="HBP13">{{HBP|B|13}}</ref>

===1990s===
[[File:Tom the Barman.jpg|250px|thumb|Tom in [[1991]]]]
In [[1991]], when [[Harry Potter]] and [[Rubeus Hagrid]] passed through the Leaky Cauldron on their way to [[Diagon Alley]], Tom greeted Hagrid like an old friend, or, at the very least, a regular. Other witches and wizards who were there at the time (including [[Doris Crockford]], [[Dedalus Diggle]], and [[Quirinus Quirrell]]) began introducing themselves to Harry, before Hagrid managed to get him away from all of them.<ref name="PS5">{{PS|B|5}}</ref>

In [[1993]], [[Cornelius Fudge]] (then [[Minister for Magic]]) asked Tom to keep an eye on [[Harry Potter]] while [[Sirius Black]] was on the loose until he was due to return to [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry|Hogwarts]].<ref name="POA3">{{POA|B|3}}</ref>

In [[1996]], the Leaky Cauldron pub was almost completely empty, aside from Tom and Rubeus Hagrid, who greeted Harry Potter when he arrived there. Tom and Harry acknowledged each other, but did not have time to speak, as Harry was busy on Hogwarts business, with Tom gloomily returning to wipe glasses.<ref name="HBP6">{{HBP|B|6}}</ref>

In [[1997]], Tom attended the [[Funeral of Albus Dumbledore|funeral]] of [[Albus Dumbledore]] and watched as his body was encased in the [[White Tomb]].<ref name="HBP30">{{HBP|B|30}}</ref>

In [[1998]], Tom was greeted by [[Bellatrix Lestrange]] (who was really [[Hermione Granger]] using [[Polyjuice Potion]]) while on her way to [[Gringotts Wizarding Bank|Gringotts]] in [[Diagon Alley]], and was surprised by how polite she was towards him.<ref name="DH26">{{DH|B|26}}</ref>

===Post-Second Wizarding War===
Tom passed away or retired during the next 19 years, since [[Hannah Abbott]] eventually took over as landlady and lived at the inn with her husband, [[Neville Longbottom]].<ref name="PM">[[DUMBLEDORE'S ARMY REUNITES AT QUIDDITCH WORLD CUP FINAL]]</ref>

==Physical appearance==
Tom was described by [[Harry Potter]] upon sight as old, "quite bald" and that he resembled a toothless [[Walnut (nut)|walnut]].<ref name="PS5"/>

==Magical abilities and skills==
*'''[[Nonverbal spell|Nonverbal]] and [[Wandless magic]]''': Tom was capable of casting simple wandless and nonverbal spells, such as [[Fire-Making Spell|lighting]] a fireplace,<ref name="POA3">{{POA|B|3}}</ref> as well being able to turn off a car alarm both non-verbally and wandlessly on the [[7 August]], [[1993]].<ref name="POAF">{{POA|F}}</ref> This implies Tom was a rather powerful and skilled [[Wizardkind|wizard]] in his own right, as casting spells non-verbally and wandlessly is highly difficult and advanced. 
*'''[[Charm]]s''': Tom was capable of producing a non-corporeal [[Patronus Charm|Patronus]],<ref name="LEGOY1"/> a clear mark of superior [[magic]]al ability as well as being able to cast simple charms like the [[Fire-Making Spell]] successfully.<ref name="POA3"/>

==Etymology==
Tom is [[Wikipedia:Diminutive|diminutive]] of the name "Thomas" which means ''infidel'' or unfaithful. It was used as a formal male given name. It also means "twin."

It is also quite likely that [[J. K. Rowling]] intentionally gave him the same first name as Tom Riddle, as the fact was commented on by Albus Dumbledore. While it is unknown if Riddle ever met the Tom who managed the Leaky Cauldron, he was annoyed by being pointed out they had the same forename. Tom Riddle disliked the fact that "Tom" was a common men's name, being those of of [[Tom Riddle Senior|his father]], and [[Thomas Riddle|his grandfather]], and desired to be known more independently.

==Behind the scenes==
[[File:TomLEGOHP1-4.png|thumb|Tom as depicted in {{LEGO|Y1}}]]
*Tom appears in the Game Boy and GBA versions of the video game adaptation of {{COS}}. In the GBA version when Harry and [[Ronald Weasley|Ron Weasley]] missed the train Harry asks him for any [[Floo Powder]] so he and Ron could get to the Burrow and take the car.
*Tom was played by [[Derek Deadman]] in {{PS|FA}}, while he was portrayed by [[Jim Tavaré]] in {{POA|FA}}. There is a difference between the two portrayals: in {{PS|FA}}, he is shown to work as the inn's barman and is straight-backed, but in {{POA|FA}}, he is clearly the innkeeper, as in the books, and appears to be a hunchback. From the in-universe part of it, one can argue that they may simply be separate characters who happen to be namesakes.
*In {{LEGO|Y1}}, if one plays as Tom, and jumps while standing still, Tom will stumble upon landing and go forward several steps.
*In {{LEGO|Y1}}, Tom can be unlocked in the first level of Year 1. First, you have to have unlocked the [[Reductor Curse]]. Then, in Gringotts, after you unlock the doors in the mainroom, use Reducto on the chest on the right. The one on the left holds Mr Ollivander.<ref name="LEGOY1"/>
*In {{HBP|FA}}, when the [[Death Eaters]] pass their way from the [[Leaky Cauldron]] to [[Diagon Alley]] to kidnap [[Garrick Ollivander]], it is unknown if Tom or a different associate was at the Leaky Cauldron.

'''Torvus' father''' was a [[Centaur]] who lived in the [[Forbidden Forest]].<ref name="HM46"/>

When his son [[Torvus]] was young, he told him about a [[Cursed Vaults|Cursed Vault]] located in the forest, and also told him not to approach it.<ref name="HM46"/>

He inherited an arrow that had been in his family for a long time.<ref name="HM46">{{HM|4|6}}</ref>

'''Professor<ref name="WWHP"/> Quentin Trimble'''<ref name="PS">{{PS|B|5}}</ref> was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who once occupied the post of [[Headmaster]] of [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]].<ref name="WWHP"/> He authored the [[List of books|textbook]] ''[[The Dark Forces: A Guide to Self-Protection]]'', a required reading for any student enrolled in [[Defence Against the Dark Arts]] [[Hogwarts subjects|class]].<ref name="HPLE">{{HPLE}} (''The Paintings of Hogwarts'')</ref>

==Biography==
===Lifetime===
Quentin attended [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]] in his youth, and was later appointed to the position of [[Headmaster]] of the school.<ref name="WWHP"/> Sometime throughout his adulthood, Quentin (or, as he was known after his appointment as Headmaster, Professor Trimble) authored the book ''[[The Dark Forces: A Guide to Self-Protection]]'', a required reading for any [[Defence Against the Dark Arts]] student.<ref name="PS"/><ref name="HPLE"/>

===Post-mortem===
[[File:Professor Quentin Trimble.jpg|175px|thumb|left|Professor Trimble's portrait in the [[Headmaster's office]]]]

Trimble was no longer the Headteacher when [[Armando Dippet]] took over in the early [[20th century]].<ref>{{TBB|R|F}} - Albus Dumbledore's notes</ref> In or prior to the end of the school term in [[1986]], Professor Trimble passed away, and a [[portrait]] was hung of him at the [[Headmaster's office]] in [[Hogwarts Castle]] so that he could offer advice and solace to future [[Headmaster]]s of the school.<ref name="WWHP"/> Unfortunately, whoever painted his name misspelled it, a mistake that was never fixed.<ref name="HPLE"/>

==Magical abilities and skills==
*'''[[Defence Against the Dark Arts]]''': Trimble was very knowledgeable in how to defend oneself from the [[Dark Arts]], as he authored ''[[The Dark Forces: A Guide to Self-Protection]]'', an authoritative text in the subject. He had very good knowledge of defensive spells and [[Dark charm]]s and how to perform them, and was highly knowledgeable of various dark [[creature]]s, meaning he had likely experienced them himself.

==Etymology==
*"Trimble" is most likely a derivation of "tremble", meaning "to shake" - fitting considering his career as an author of books against the [[Dark Arts|dark forces]]. As the shaky [[Quirinus Quirrell|Professor Quirrell]] was the [[Defence Against the Dark Arts]] teacher in the year that [[Harry Potter]] purchased Trimble’s book, it is likely to be a reference to that.

==Behind the scenes==
*Professor Trimble's name is considered to be misspelled "Quintin Trimble" on his [[portrait]] in the [[Harry Potter (film series)|films]].<ref name="HPLE"/> But the truth is that Quintin is a variant of spelling. It may be a hint to the fact that he also was the 15th Hogwarts headmaster (15th is 'quindecim' in Latin).

'''Troy''' was an [[Ireland|Irish]] [[wizardkind|wizard]] who played as the [[Chaser]] for the [[Irish National Quidditch team]] during the [[1994]] [[Quidditch World Cup]]. He appeared to be the prominent Chaser, scoring the first goal of the match after the [[Bulgaria]]n [[Chaser]] [[Alexei Levski]] lost the [[Quaffle]]. He and [[Quigley]] lifted the Quidditch Cup of [[1994]] into the air in the [[Top Box]] after the Irish team had won the tournament.<ref>{{GOF|B|8}}</ref>

==Etymology==
"Troy" is a surname that originally denoted a person from the city of Troyes in [[France]]. This was also the name of the ancient city that was besieged by the Greeks in Homer's 'Iliad'.

==Behind the scenes==
*The part of Troy was played by [[Phil Mulryne]] in {{GOF|FA}}.

'''Mallory Twiddle''' was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who wrote to the ''[[Daily Prophet]]'' in [[July]] [[1998]] to complain about how [[Gringotts Wizarding Bank|Gringotts]] was using [[sphinx]]es to guard its high security vaults.<ref name="wizardst">"[http://www.hplex.info/wizards/a-z/t.html Wizards, Witches and Beings: T]" on the Harry Potter Lexicon</ref><ref name="dp">"[http://www.hplex.info/about/sources/source_dp.html Daily Prophet newsletters]" on The Harry Potter Lexicon</ref> According to Twiddle, he ran into one of these sphinxes and spent an hour trying to solve its riddles, and was eventually chased out of the bank.<ref name="wizardst" />

==Etymology==
The name "Mallory" comes from an English surname which meant "unfortunate" in Norman French.

==Behind the scenes==
*In {{DH}}, a [[dragon]] is shown guarding the high security vaults at [[Gringotts Wizarding Bank|Gringotts]], contradicting the earlier revelation that sphinxes were used as guards in the ''[[The Daily Prophet (real-world)|Daily Prophet Newsletters]]''. However, this dragon escaped during the [[Break-in of Gringotts Wizarding Bank (1998)|Gringotts break-in]] on [[1 May]], [[1998]], causing substantial damage to the bank in the process. Twiddle's letter was published in the [[31 July]], [[1998]] issue of the ''Daily Prophet Newsletters'',<ref name="dp" /> so it's possible that Gringotts decided to switch to using sphinxes to guard its high security vaults after the break-in, in the hope of preventing further such incidents from occurring.

==Appearances==
*''[[The Daily Prophet (real-world)|Daily Prophet Newsletters]]''

==Notes and references==

'''These Ministry Guards''' were [[Great Britain|British]] [[Wizardkind|wizards]] who guarded the [[Muggle-Born Registration Commission]] alongside [[Corban Yaxley]] and others in [[1997]].

==History==
In [[1997]], these two Ministry Guard were stationed to guard the [[Muggle-Born Registration Commission courtroom]] during the trial of [[Mary Cattermole]], overlooked by both [[Dolores Umbridge]] and [[Corban Yaxley]]. However, [[Harry Potter]], [[Ronald Weasley]] and [[Hermione Granger]], both disguised using [[Polyjuice Potion]] as [[Albert Runcorn]], [[Reginald Cattermole]] and [[Mafalda Hopkirk]] respectively, hijacked and stopped the corrupt trial, and [[Stunning Spell|stunned]] these guards, along with Umbridge and Yaxley with offensive [[duelling]] [[spell]]s, and rescued Mary Cattermole from being given a false and wrongful sentence by Umbridge.<ref>{{LEGO|Y2}}</ref><ref>{{DH|F1}}</ref>

==Appearances==
*{{DH|F1}} {{Possible}}
*{{LEGO 2}} {{1st}}

{{Quote|Oh, she was perfect, obviously. Perfect deliberation, divination, and desperation or whatever the hell it is — we all went for a quick drink in the [[Three Broomsticks Inn|Three Broomsticks]] after and you should've heard Twycross going on about her — I'll be surprised if he doesn't pop the question soon —|[[Ronald Weasley|Ron Weasley]] on Twycross's favourable treatment of [[Hermione Granger]]|Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince}}
'''Wilkie Twycross''' (b. before [[1979]]) was a [[Great Britain|British]] [[Wizardkind|wizard]] and employee of the [[British Ministry of Magic]], who was the [[Apparition Instructor]] at [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]] to students who were age seventeen or approaching age seventeen and wish to obtain a licence to [[Apparition|Apparate]].<ref name="HBP18"/>  

==Biography==
{{Quote|The important things to remember when [[Apparition|Apparating]] are the three D's.|Wilkie Twycross|Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince}}Twycross was described as "''oddly colourless, with transparent eyelashes, wispy hair, and an insubstantial air, as though a single gust of wind might blow him away''." [[Harry Potter]], upon meeting him, wondered whether this was because of the large amount of Apparating and Disapparating he did.<ref name="HBP18">{{HBP|B|18}}</ref> 

Many of the [[sixth year]] students in Twycross's [[1997]] [[Apparition (class)|Apparition class]] disliked and called him various insults, inspired by the "Three D's of Apparition" that he tried to teach them. The most moderate of these were "[[dog]]-breath" and "[[Faeces|dung]]-head." Perhaps because of this, Twycross seemed very fond of his few good students, such as [[Hermione Granger]].<ref name="HBP18"/>

==Magical abilities and skills==
*'''[[Apparition]]''': As the [[Apparition Instructor]] for [[sixth year]] Hogwarts students, Twycross would have been highly accomplished in apparition as a form of [[magic]]al transportation. He had a very sophisticated understanding of the art of apparition, teaching his students the specifics needed to apparate successfully and the [[Splinching|dangers]] of it, showing his proficiency in this field.<ref name="HBP18"/>

==Etymology==
''{{w|Wilkie}}'' is a surname used in [[Scotland]] and [[England]] possibly a diminutive of William. ''{{w|Twycross}}'' is a small village and civil parish in Leicestershire, England. Also ''twy-'' is an archaic form of ''two'' so his surname could literally mean ''two-cross'', or one who crosses between two places; hence, one who Apparates.

==Behind the scenes==
*It is interesting to note that Rowling was reading Wilkie Collins' ''The Moonstone'' when she was writing {{HBP}},{{fact}} so it is possible that it is where she got the name.

===Translations===
*Czech: ''Wilkie Křížek'' (''křížek'' "little cross")
*Dutch: ''Wilco Draaisma'' (''draai'' "turn")
*French: ''Wilkie Tycross''
*Hungarian: ''Wilkie Derreng''
*Japanese: ''ウィルキー・トワイクロス''
*Russian: ''Уилки Двукрест {{c|Wilkie Dvukrest}}''
*Ukrainian: ''Вілкі Твайкрос {{c|Vilki Tvaykros}}''
The following languages are the same as the original:

|

|

|
*Polish
|}

'''Mr Umbridge''' was a [[Squib]], son of [[Wizardkind|wizard]] [[Orford Umbridge]] and [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] [[Ellen Cracknell]].<ref name="PM">{{WW|dolores-umbridge}}</ref>

==Biography==
Umbridge was born in [[1973]] or earlier to the [[Wizardkind|wizard]] [[Orford Umbridge]] and [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] [[Ellen Cracknell]], and had an older sister named [[Dolores Umbridge|Dolores]]. His status as a [[Squib]] would often lead his [[Orford Umbridge|father]] and sister to blame his [[Ellen Cracknell|mother]] for being the cause of it, which led the [[Umbridge family|family]] to be fraught with tensions. When Dolores was fifteen years old, his parents separated and he would return to the [[Muggle world]] with his mother, while his sister would stay with his father in the [[wizarding world]] and would never speak of him again.<ref name="PM"/>

'''Orford Umbridge''' was the father of [[Dolores Umbridge]] and a [[squib]] [[Dolores Umbridge's brother|son]]. An unambitious [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who worked at the [[British Ministry of Magic|Ministry of Magic]] as a [[Magical Maintenance Department|floor mopper]], Orford later became a source of embarrassment for his daughter and would later disappear from sight at his daughter's request in exchange for a small financial allowance.<ref name="PM">{{WW|dolores-umbridge}}</ref>

==Biography==

===Family life===
Orford Umbridge married [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] [[Ellen Cracknell]] and they had two children, a daughter Dolores and a son who was born a [[Squib]]. The marriage was not a happy one and both Orford and Dolores would blame Ellen as the cause of Dolores' squib brother. When Dolores was fifteen, Orford and Ellen separated and Orford took their daughter to live with him while Ellen took their son and disappeared into the [[Muggle world]]. He would never see his wife or son again.<ref name="PM"/>

===Ministry career===
Orford worked at the [[Ministry of Magic]] in the [[Magical Maintenance Department|Department of Magical Maintenance]] where he would most often mop the floors. His unambitious attitude towards his career was a source of irritation for his daughter as she began her own career and rose through the Ministry's ranks. He was so despised by his own daughter that by the time Dolores was promoted to the head of the [[Improper Use of Magic Office]], she was able to persuade him to take an early retirement. She then promised him a small financial allowance in exchange that he quietly disappear out of public sight.<ref name="PM"/>

===Early retirement===
Whenever people asked her if she is related to the Umbridge who used to mop floors in the Ministry, she would use her sweetest smile (which indicates her suppressed rage) to deny all connections, and falsely claimed that her deceased father was an esteemed member of the [[Wizengamot]]. Nasty things tend to happen to people who ask about Orford, or anything else Dolores did not want to talk about, so people who wished to be on her good side would pretend to believe her false heritage.<ref name="PM"/>

Whether or not Dolores kept her promise with her father in the small allowance is unknown, but she wanted to sever all ties with him to give herself a better image; the two clearly have little to no contact as a result. With Dolores arrested for her crimes involving the [[Muggle-Born Registration Commission]], Orford definitely lost his pittance (assuming he was still alive at the time).<ref name="PM"/>

==Personality and traits==
Orford was an unambitious man who was content with his career as a janitor, mostly mopping floors in the Ministry of Magic. His lack of motivation allowed him to be pressured by his daughter into taking an early retirement in exchange for a small monthly allowance, leaving public sight without any commotions. He seemed to be unaware or tolerant of how his daughter would deny any connections with him, as she would falsely claim her father has died as a distinguished member of the [[Wizengamot]].<ref name="PM"/>

Orford seemed to have mixed feelings for Muggles as he was tolerant to marry a Muggle woman, [[Ellen Cracknell]], but blamed her heritage for being the cause of their [[Dolores Umbridge's brother|son]] to be a [[Squib]]. Finding shame in his son's lack of magical abilities, it caused his marriage with Ellen to deteriorate and eventually they divorced, with the magical and non-magical sides leaving each other, never again to cross paths.<ref name="PM"/>

==Relationships==
===Dolores Umbridge===
[[File:Dolores Umbridge.JPG|150px|thumb|Dolores Umbridge, his daughter]]
Orford's first child and only daughter [[Dolores Umbridge]] was born with magical powers; hence he took custody of her when he divorced his Muggle wife. However, while Orford possesses magical lineage (while Dolores detests Ellen for being a Muggle), his daughter still despises him for his unambitious personality towards his own career as a janitorial employee of the Ministry of Magic. Dolores found Orford to be a source of embarrassment while she was climbing the ranks of the Ministry, and bribed him into taking an early retirement so he can quietly drop out of public sight. Dolores callously denied all connections to Orford Umbridge and instead invented a deceased father of an esteemed career. Orford was either unaware or tolerant of how his daughter shunned him aside, as he accepted her small, monthly allowance in exchange for his absence from public.<ref name="PM"/>

===Ellen Cracknell===
What attracted Orford to [[Ellen Cracknell]] is unknown, but their relationship was strained and unhappy after [[marriage]]. After their [[Dolores Umbridge's brother|son]] was discovered to be a Squib, Orford would blame his wife's Muggle heritage as the cause of it. Tensions reached a head when Dolores reached 15 years old, and the two divorced, never again seeing each other.<ref name="PM"/>

===Son===
Orford stopped loving his [[Dolores Umbridge's brother|son]] after discovering the boy was a Squib and often looked down on him while blaming Ellen for being the cause. When the couple divorced, the boy went with Ellen back into the Muggle world, and Orford never saw his son again.<ref name="PM"/>

{{Quote|Virtutes, Archangeli, Angeli, Principatus, Dominationes, Seraphin, Cherubin, Throni.|Inscription on Professor Undercliffe's portrait|Harry Potter Limited Edition}}
'''Professor Fytherley Undercliffe''' was a [[wizardkind|wizard]] and a [[Headmaster]] of [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]] in the [[16th century|sixteenth century]].<ref name="HPLE">{{HPLE|PA}}</ref>

Undercliffe had a [[portrait]] that was painted in [[1531]].<ref name="HPLE" /> It was hung in the [[Headmaster's office]] at Hogwarts after his death.<ref name="HPLE" /><ref name="DOD" />

==Behind the scenes==
*The portrait seems to be a direct reference to [http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d9/Archdeacon_by_Repin.jpg an 1877 portrait of an Orthodox protodeacon holding a walking stick], by [[Wikipedia:Ilya Repin|Ilya Yefimovich Repin]]. The same portrait appears at the [[Grand Staircase]] in {{POA|F}} when the [[Fat Lady]] is missing.
*On the DVD of {{COS|F}}, Professor Undercliffe's portrait is erroneously referred to as a portrait of "''Salazar Slytherin himself''". Why this mistake was made is, as of yet, unclear.
*The inscription on Professor Fytherley Undercliffe's portrait frame, "''Virtutes, Archangeli, Angeli, Principatus, Dominationes, Seraphin, Cherubin, Throni''" are all names of eight [[Wikipedia:Christian angelic hierarchy|hosts of angels]].

This '''individual''' was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who became the [[professor]] of [[Defence Against the Dark Arts]] at [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]] for the [[1985–1986 school year]]. However, because of [[Tom Riddle|Lord Voldemort]]'s [[Jinx on the post of Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher|jinx]] on the post, this individual needed to be replaced by the end of the year.

When [[William Weasley|Bill Weasley]] proceeded to teach [[Jacob's sibling]] the [[Fire-Making Spell]], he implied that the spell should have been taught in Defence Against the Dark Arts, but assumed Jacob's sibling had not learned it in the class, for the professor was hardly around or teaching, which Jacob's sibling concurred.<ref name="professor">{{HM}}, Year 2, Chapter 6 (''Bill Weasley'')</ref> According to his students, he was rarely present, making it difficult for them to learn from him.
==Appearances==
*{{HM}} {{1st Mention}}

{{Dialogue a-b-a-b-a-b|Balding wizard|What's up, Albert?|Harry Potter (as Albert Runcorn)|This lot need to leave before you seal the exits|We've been told to seal all exits and not let anyone –|Are you contradicting me? Would you like me to have your family tree examined, like I had Dirk Cresswell's?|Sorry! I didn't mean nothing, Albert, but I thought… I thought they were in for questioning and…|Their blood is pure. Purer than many of yours, I daresay. Off you go|This wizard tries to stop "[[Albert Runcorn]]" (actually [[Harry Potter]] in [[Polyjuice Potion|disguise]]) and [[Muggle-born]]s in for questioning during the [[Infiltration of the Ministry of Magic]].|Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows}}
This '''individual''' was a [[wizardkind|wizard]] and a [[British Ministry of Magic|Ministry of Magic]] worker in the late-[[1990s]].<ref name="DH12">{{DH|B|12}}</ref>

==Biography==
On the morning of [[2 September]], [[1997]], this wizard ran into "[[Albert Runcorn]]" (actually [[Harry Potter]] in disguise) while entering the Ministry headquarters through the fireplaces in the [[Atrium]]. At first he seemed annoyed, but he excused himself and hurried away nervously when he noticed who he had bumped into.<ref name="DH12"/>

Later, when there were [[Infiltration of the Ministry of Magic|intruders detected]] in the Ministry, this wizard was sent to the [[Atrium]] in order to seal all exits and stop everyone from leaving. When "[[Albert Runcorn]]" (actually [[Harry Potter]]), "[[Mafalda Hopkirk]]" ([[Hermione Granger]]) and "[[Reginald Cattermole]]" ([[Ronald Weasley]]) were leading [[Muggle-born]]s in for [[Muggle-Born Registration Commission|questioning]] out to freedom, the wizard seemed aprehensive as to let them pass, but was intimidated by "Runcorn"'s threats and let them pass as [[Corban Yaxley|Yaxley]] emerged from one of the lifts. Harry, impersonating Runcorn, then told Yaxley that the balding wizard was trying to get the [[Muggle-born]]s out of the Ministry and punched him sending him flying through the air just before he jumped into one of the fireplaces and left the Ministry.<ref name="DH13">{{DH|B|13}}</ref>

==Appearances==
*{{DH}} {{1st}}

==Notes and references==

This '''individual''' was an [[United States of America|American]] [[Non-magic people|No-Maj]] who worked as an employee at the [[Steen National Bank]] in the [[20th century]].

==Biography==
On [[6 December]], [[1926]], when [[Newton Scamander]] went into the bank to find his escaped [[Newton Scamander's niffler|niffler]], the employee, suspicious of Newt due his furtive glances around the bank, asked him if he needed any help to which Newt replied that he was only waiting.<ref>{{FB|S|8}}</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*The Employee was portrayed by [[Cory Peterson]] in ''[[Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)|Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them]]''.

==Appearances==
*{{FB|S}} {{1st}}
*{{FB|F}}

This '''individual''' (fl. [[1981]]) was a [[Great Britain|British]] [[wizardkind|wizard]] who held a clerical post at the [[Council of Magical Law]] in the [[1980s]]. This wizard was present at [[Igor Karkaroff]]'s hearing in order to provide [[Death Eaters|Death Eater]] names, and provided [[Bartemius Crouch Senior|Bartemius Crouch Snr]], who presided over the Council, with records of the [[Death Eaters]] already caught by the Ministry.<ref name="GOFF21">{{GOF|F}} - Chapter 21 (''The Pensieve'')</ref>

{{Quote|In the second row, a dumpy wizard with a large black moustache leaned close to whisper in the ear of his neighbour, a frizzy-haired witch. She smirked and nodded.|Description|Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix}}
This '''individual''' was a [[wizardkind|wizard]] and member of the [[Wizengamot]] in the mid-[[1990s]]. He was dumpy and heavily-moustached. On [[12 August]], he was present at [[Harry Potter]]'s [[Disciplinary hearing of Harry Potter|disciplinary hearing]], appearing highly sceptical of [[Arabella Figg]]'s testimony, whispering about it to [[Unidentified frizzy-haired Wizengamot member|the witch sitting next to him]]. He and his neighbour later voted in favour of [[Harry Potter|Harry]]'s conviction.<ref name="OP8">{{OOTP|B|8}}</ref>

This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Unidentified_Durmstrang_students","to":"Unidentified Durmstrang students"}],"pages":{"153162":{"pageid":153162,"ns":0,"title":"Unidentified Durmstrang students","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"The following is a list of '''[[Durmstrang Institute]] students''' whose exact identity is not known.

==Unidentified Durmstrang boy (I)==
[[File:Unidentified Durmstrang Boy (I).png|250px|thumb]]

This '''individual''' was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who attended [[Durmstrang Institute]], and came to [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]] for the [[Triwizard Tournament]] in [[1994]]. While he and his classmates were coming in down the [[Great Hall]], he blew out a fiery bird-symbol that represented the school. He put his name into the [[Goblet of Fire]], but [[Viktor Krum]] was chosen as his school's [[Triwizard Tournament|Triwizard Champion]]. He appeared, watching Krum, in every task, and danced at the [[Yule Ball]]. At the end of the year after [[Cedric Diggory]] had been murdered, the student attended the [[Memorial feast to Cedric Diggory]].
;Behind the scenes
*This student is portrayed by [[Ponciano Almeida]] in {{GOF|FA}}.

;Appearances
*{{GOF|F}} {{1st}}

==Unidentified Durmstrang boy (II)==
This '''individual''' was a wizard who attended Durmstrang Institute in the 1990s. He was one of the students who travelled to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry for the Triwizard Tournament and put his name in the Goblet of Fire, however Viktor Krum was chosen as Champion. He also attended the memorial feast of Cedric Diggory following his murder.

;Behind the scenes
*This student is played by [[Oliver Miceli]] in {{GOF|FA}}.

;Appearances
*{{GOF|F}} {{1st}}

==Unidentified Durmstrang boy (III)==
{{Dialogue a-b|Durmstrang student|Would you please come to the ball with me?|Ravenclaw student|Yes.|The students|Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)}}
This individual was a student at Durmstrang Institute. During the Triwizard Tournament at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, he asked a [[Ravenclaw]] [[Unidentified Ravenclaw student asked to the Yule Ball by a Durmstrang student|student]] to go to the Yule Ball with him, which she agreed to.

;Appearances
*{{GOF|F}}

}}This '''individual''' was an [[United States of America|American]] [[Wizardkind|Wizard]] who worked as an [[executioner]] for [[Magical Congress of the United States of America|Magical Congress]] in [[1926]].<ref name="FBS">{{FB|S}}</ref>

==Biography==
Along with [[Bernadette]] and [[Unidentified executioner (I)|another witch]], he assisted in the execution of [[Newton Scamander]] and [[Porpentina Goldstein]] after being sentenced to [[Death]] by [[Gellert Grindelwald]] (disguised as [[Percival Graves]]) for violating the [[International Statute of Wizarding Secrecy]]. The execution was stopped when Newt and Tina were rescued by a [[Swooping Evil]].<ref name="FBS"/>

During the fight, Newt knocked him out by whacking him in the face with his (Newt's) handcuffs.<ref name="FBS"/>

==Behind the scenes==
*The executioner was portrayed by [[Cristian Solimeno]] in ''[[Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)|Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them]]''.
*He was the only of the three executioners not to be mentioned in the [[Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them: The Original Screenplay|original screenplay]].

==Appearances==
*{{FB|S}} {{1st}}
*{{FB|F}}

{{Quote|Aaaarrg!|The wizard as he falls|Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)}}
This '''man''' was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who attended the [[1994 Quidditch World Cup]] in [[August]] of [[1994]].<ref name="GOFF"/>

==Biography==
Born sometime prior to [[1994]], he attended the [[1994 Quidditch World Cup]], supporting [[Bulgaria]]. He attempted to flee when the [[Death Eaters]] came and began [[Levicorpus|levitating]] people and [[Fire-Making Spell|burning]] [[Charmed Tent|tents]], but was pushed back, falling to the ground and screaming. [[Harry Potter]], [[Ronald Weasley|Ron Weasley]] and [[Hermione Granger]] witnessed the man's falling as they emerged from their [[Perkins's tent|tent]], but they did not try to help him. It is unknown what happened to him; he either managed to escape, was trampled by the crowd, or perhaps was [[Killing Curse|killed]] by the [[Death Eaters]].<ref name="GOFF">{{GOF|F}}</ref>

==Appearances==
*{{GOF|F}} {{1st}}

This '''individual''' (fl. [[1927]]) was a [[France|French]] [[Non-magique|Non-Magique]] [[police]]man.<ref name="COG48"/>

==Biography==
In [[1927]], he was guarding near [[Unidentified Magical Statue|the entrance]] to [[Place Cachée]]. When [[Newton Scamander|Newt Scamander]] and [[Jacob Kowalski]] arrived at [[Paris]] to investigate, Newt used the [[Confundus Charm]] on the Policeman to distract him for a moment.<ref name="COG48">{{COG|S|48}}</ref>

This '''individual''' was a [[British Ministry of Magic|Ministry of Magic]] Official. On [[2 September]], [[1997]], he passed by [[Harry Potter]] ([[Polyjuice Potion|disguised]] as [[Albert Runcorn]]) while under his [[Cloak of Invisibility|Invisibility Cloak]] on Level One of the Ministry of Magic. The wizard was murmuring instructions to a floating quill scribbling on a trail of parchment.<ref name="DH13">{{DH|B|13}}</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*His quill was possibly a [[Self-Writing Quill]] or a [[Quick-Quotes Quill]].

This '''goblin''' worked at the British [[Gringotts Wizarding Bank]] in the [[1990s]] after [[Tom Riddle|Voldemort]] fell in [[1981]] and later rose to power and took over the [[British Ministry of Magic|Ministry of Magic]] in [[1998]].

==Biography==
On [[31 July]], [[1991]], this [[goblin]] was present at [[Gringotts Wizarding Bank]] when [[Harry Potter]] came to pick up his money in [[Vault 687]].<ref name="PSF">{{PS|F}}</ref>

The goblin continued working in [[Gringotts Wizarding Bank|Gringotts]] when [[Tom Riddle|Lord Voldemort]] took over the [[Wizarding world]] and was present when [[Harry Potter]], [[Ronald Weasley|Ron Weasley]] and [[Hermione Granger]] went to Gringotts to [[Break-in of Gringotts Wizarding Bank (1998)|steal]] [[Helga Hufflepuff's Cup]] in the [[Lestrange Vault]].<ref name="DHF2">{{DH|F2}}</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*The goblin was played by [[Mike Edmonds]] in the film adaptation of {{PS}} and [[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2|Part 2]] of the film adaptation of {{DH}}.

This '''goblin''' worked at [[Gringotts Wizarding Bank]] during the wizard management in [[1997]]-[[1998]], after the Ministry fell to the Death Eaters.<ref name="DHF2"/>

==Biography==
===1998===
He was present at the bank when [[Harry Potter]], [[Hermione Granger]], [[Ronald Weasley|Ron Weasley]], and [[Griphook]] hosted a break-in in order to retrieve one of [[Tom Riddle|Lord Voldemort]]'s [[Horcrux]]es, [[Helga Hufflepuff's Cup]], from the [[Lestrange Vault]].<ref name="DHF2">{{DH|F2}}</ref>

===Death===
When the Gringotts dragon started to escape, the goblin became shocked and most likely got killed by it when he appeared not to be running from his seat, but his fate is unknown.

{{Quote|Welcome to Gringotts, Mr Potter. To access the vaults, you must collect all [[Gringotts Wizarding Bank paperwork forms|the forms]], and then hand them to the Goblin outside the door.|The Goblin greeting [[Harry Potter]]|Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (video game)}}
This '''[[goblin]]''' was a guard at [[Gringotts Wizarding Bank]] in [[1991]]. He wore a uniform of scarlet and gold, and stood by the bank's outer doors to greet visitors. He was described as having a pointed beard, a swarthy, clever face, and was about a head shorter than [[Harry Potter]] was when he was eleven.<ref name="PS5">{{PS|B|5}}</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*In {{PS|FA}} he appears outside [[Vault 713]] in a photo in the [[Daily Prophet]]. He is seen talking to the [[Gringotts Head Goblin|Head Goblin]] and then walking away. The goblin was played by [[Binde Johal]] in the film.
*In the film and game he doesn't have a pointed beard.

==History==
He was one of the witnesses when some of [[Newton Scamander|Newt Scamander]]'s creatures escaped from his [[Newton Scamander's suitcase|briefcase]] that year.<ref name="FBS">{{FB|S}}</ref>

When a [[NYPD Police Officer No. 743|policeman]] asked questions about the situation, the drunken hobo was about to tell about what he really saw while [[Unidentified housewife|another witness]] thought it was gas explosion, his memories were [[Memory Charm|obliviated]] by Newt leaving him and the crowd to agree that it was actually gas.<ref name="FBS">{{FB|S}}</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*The hobo was portrayed by [[Paul Birchard]] in ''[[Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)|Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them]]''.

This '''unnamed [[Ireland|Irish]] man''' met [[Rubeus Hagrid]] in the [[Leaky Cauldron]] in [[1990]]. He sold Hagrid the [[Fluffy|three-headed dog]] he owned. Hagrid named this dog [[Fluffy]], and, the [[1991|following year]], lent him to [[Albus Dumbledore]], who used him to guard the [[Philosopher's Stone]].<ref>{{PS|F}}</ref>


==Behind the scenes==

*In the novel {{PS}}, [[Rubeus Hagrid|Hagrid]] states that he bought [[Fluffy]] from "a [[Greece|Greek]] [[Greek man|man]]", rather than "an Irish feller,". Because of this change in the film, it loses [[J. K. Rowling]]'s reference to [[Wikipedia:Greek mythology|Greek mythology]], in which there was a three-head dog, [[Wikipedia:Cerberus|Cerberus]], that guarded the gates of [[Wikipedia:Hades|Hades]]. However, [[Steve Kloves]], the film's screenwriter, stated that he originally used "Greek chappie," but did not know how the line got changed.<ref>[http://www.hp-lexicon.org/about/books/ps/rg-ps11.html Reader's Guide to Chapter 11 of ''Philosopher's Stone''] on The Harry Potter Lexicon</ref>

This '''[[Charms (class)|Charms]]'''<ref name="Charms">On the subject of the [[Unlocking Charm]], this Professor says that he personally wouldn't teach it so early on in a wizard's studies, meaning that [[Charms (class)|Charms]] is his subject, as this spell is taught in [[first year]] Charms.</ref> '''[[Professor]]''' was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who taught at [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]] some two hundred years after the publication of [[Miranda Goshawk]]'s ''[[Book of Spells]]''. He was fairly familiar with this book's contents, and once helped a Hogwarts student in navigating and learning its [[spell]]s.<ref name="WBS">{{WBS}}</ref>

==History==
===Early life===
This individual was presumably born somewhere in [[Great Britain]]. He may have attended [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]], where he would most likely have gotten high marks in the subject of Charms. Sometime in his adult life, he took on the position of Charms Professor at Hogwarts.

===Teaching with the ''Book of Spells''===
One night, he was in the [[Restricted Section]] of the [[Hogwarts Library]] when he happened upon a young Hogwarts student. After admonishing them for being there, he promised not to take any [[house points]] and inquired as to what they were doing there. The student produced a note indicating that they were permitted to be in that section to check out a copy of ''Book of Spells''. The Professor was impressed that this student got permission for such a task, and offered to guide them through the book's contents.<ref name="WBS"/>

Together, the two explored the old book, the Professor giving occasional advice on how to complete the book's assigned tasks and offering his own opinions on Goshawk's words, as well as awarding house points when the student achieved a particularly remarkable task. In time, the student had learned all the spells the book had to offer, and the Professor expressed his pride in his student.<ref name="WBS"/>

His favourite [[spell]] was the [[Bird-Conjuring Charm]].<ref> See [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MOoAFUUyycA&feature=BFa&list=ELtMQLA1ScYkc this video].</ref>

==Magical abilities and skills==
*'''[[Charm]]s''': As a [[Charms Master]], he was naturally learned in the subject. He could easily recognise and advise on all the spells printed in ''Book of Spells'', including those that had merely been written in the margins by former students. He was also highly proficient in the casting of numerous charms, such as being capable of casting the [[Muffliato Charm]] with proper reflexes to prevent a student from harm when the ''Book of Spells'' conjured a greenhouse full of [[Mandrake]]s.<ref name="WBS"/>
*'''[[Magizoology]]''': He could identify a number of [[magic]]al [[creature]]s conjured forth by ''Book of Spells'' on sight. He was also knowledgeable in dealing with them; for instance, he knew that a [[Kelpie]] can only be subdued by bridling it.<ref name="WBS"/>
*'''[[Herbology]]''': He could also identify magical plants that ''Book of Spells'' spawned, such as [[Mandrake]]s and [[Devil's Snare]], as well as advise on how to deal with them.<ref name="WBS"/>
*'''Logical thinking''': This wizard possessed a great deal of logical thinking skills, a trait rare in a wizard. He was able to quickly adapt to the challenges ''Book of Spells'' provided and give sufficient advice to guide the student reading the book through them.<ref name="WBS"/>

==Behind the scenes==
*The Professor was voiced by [[Rupert Degas]] in the English edition of {{WBS}}.
*His reaction to the player's permission note depends on their [[Hogwarts Houses|House]]. For example, if the player's character a [[Gryffindor]], he will say that hopes they know what they are doing, and if they are a [[Slytherin]], he will assume their permission note is falsified, and that they forged the signature.

==Appearances==
*{{WBS}} {{1st}} {{C|Voice only}}

This '''[[Merpeople|merman]]''' fell in [[love]] with a young [[Wizardkind|witch]], [[Mirabella Plunkett]].<ref name="PSG"/><ref name="COSG"/><ref name="POAG"/>

==Biography==
This merman lived in the waters of [[Loch Lomond]], [[Scotland]]. At some point in his life, he met the young [[Wizardkind|witch]], [[Mirabella Plunkett]] who was on holiday in the area, and two subsequently fell in [[love]]. However, due to Mirabella being a [[human]] and him being a merman, Mirabella's parents strongly objected to their relationship and forbade her to marry him. However in response, Mirabella [[Transfiguration|transfigured]] herself into a [[haddock]], and was never seen by humans again. Therefore, it is possible that the two later married with them both inhabiting the [[water]]s as aquatic creatures.<ref name="PSG">{{PS|G}}</ref><ref name="COSG">{{COS|G}}</ref><ref name="POAG">{{POA|G}}</ref>

This '''individual''' (fl. [[1997]]) was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who was visiting the [[British Ministry of Magic|Ministry of Magic]] during the [[Infiltration of the Ministry of Magic]], on [[2 September]], [[1997]]. He wore a black cloak and hat, and had a big white curled moustache. He was rudely pushed aside by [[Corban Yaxley|Yaxley]] who was preventing [[Harry Potter]], [[Ronald Weasley]] and [[Hermione Granger]] to leave the Ministry.<ref>{{DH|F1}} - Chapter 13 (''Lifting the Locket'')</ref>

**[[Department of International Magical Cooperation]]
}}This '''individual''' was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who worked for [[Bartemius Crouch Senior|Bartemius Crouch Snr]] until Crouch's death in [[1995]].<ref name="GOFF">{{GOF|F}}</ref>

==Biography==
In [[1981]] after [[Tom Riddle|Lord Voldemort]]'s downfall he attended the trial of [[Igor Karkaroff]] in which Karkaroff named [[Death Eaters]].<ref name="GOFF"/>

In [[1994]] he attended the [[Quidditch World Cup]] between [[Ireland]] and [[Bulgaria]]. When the [[Dark Mark]] appeared in the sky he helped [[Bartemius Crouch Senior|Bartemius Crouch Snr]] and some other wizards and witches to find the "[[Bartemius Crouch Junior|man]]" in the ruins of the [[Roberts's campsite|campsite]] owned by [[Roberts]].<ref name="GOFF"/>

==Behind the scenes==
*He is portrayed by [[Campbell Graham]] in {{GOF|FA}}.

==Appearances==
*{{GOF|F}} {{1st}}

==Biography==
He and [[Unidentified police officer (II)|fellow officer]] caught [[Newton Scamander]] and [[Jacob Kowalski]] believing that they were robbing a jewellery store before they saw a [[lion]] that escaped from the [[Central Park Zoo]], leaving the two suspects to escape.<ref name="FBS">{{FB|S}}</ref>

Two '''wizards''' were in the [[Hog's Head Inn]] in [[1995]] on the day several [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry|Hogwarts]] students met there to discuss the formation of their own [[Defence Against the Dark Arts]] [[Dumbledore's Army|group]]. They wore cloaks and sat in the corner. [[Harry Potter]] would have thought they were [[Dementor]]s, had they not been speaking in strong [[Yorkshire]] accents.<ref name="OOTP16">{{OOTP|B|16}}</ref>

I’d like to see him fly with his [[Knee-reversal hex|knees on back to front]], the great hairy hog.|Excerpt from [[Gertie Keddle's diary]]|Quidditch Through the Ages (real)}} There were '''unnamed Kwidditch players''', probably living on the edge of [[Queerditch Marsh]] in [[Manchester]], [[England]] in the [[11th century]]. They were playing [[Quidditch|Kwidditch]], and their game took place over the marsh, between two trees, serving as a primitive form of modern [[Goalpost|goal posts]], and was recorded by [[Gertie Keddle]] in her [[Gertie Keddle's diary|diary]]. Each of them had his own flying [[broomstick]]. Their leather ball (an early equivalent of today's [[Quaffle]]) accidentally fell into Keddle's bowl of cabbage and through her window. {{Quote|Rebel leader in the 18th century goblin rebellion.|[[Chocolate Frog Card]]|Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (video game)}}
'''Urg the Unclean '''(fl. [[18th century]]) was a [[goblin]] rebel who became notorious for having led the [[18th century]] [[Goblin Rebellions]].<ref name="PAvg">{{POA|G}}</ref>

At some point in his life he was publicly dunked in a village pond by a group of young [[Wizardkind|wizards]].<ref name="WOMBAT">Third [[Wizards' Ordinary Magic and Basic Aptitude Test]] from {{JKRS}}.</ref> This event precipitated one of the bloody rebellions in which Urg himself was the dissident leader.<ref>This piece of information comes from the third [[Wizards' Ordinary Magic and Basic Aptitude Test|W.O.M.B.A.T.]] featured in {{JKRS}}. Question 2 (''Part One - Magical History'') is "Which of the following did NOT provoke one of the bloody goblin rebellions of the 17th and 18th centuries? Choose ONE.", and one of the possible answers is "''The public ducking in the village pond, by a gang of young wizards, of goblin activist Urg the Unclean''". As one of the other answers is known for certain to be false ("''The imprisonment of the notoriously violent Hodrod the Horny-Handed, who had attempted to kill three wizards ''" — the ''[[The Daily Prophet (real-world)|Daily Prophet Newsletters]]'' reveal that [[Hodrod the Horny-Handed]] was indeed imprisoned for attempting to kill three wizards, but this happened in [[1999]], during the [[Chipping Clodbury riot]]), then all of the other answers must be true, including the one about Urg the Unclean.</ref> For his role in the [[Goblin Rebellions]], he was featured on one [[Chocolate Frog Card]].<ref name="PAvg"/>

When [[Ronald Weasley|Ron Weasley]] sat his [[fourth year]] [[History of Magic]] final, he forgot some of the names of the goblin rebels, and thus invented a few as cover, stating that this was easy because "they're all called stuff like [[Bodrod the Bearded]] and Urg the Unclean."<ref>{{GOF}}</ref>

{{Quote|He reaped the bitter fruits of his hubris, but his name will live forever. Some would call that a victory. Still… the loss of such a valuable artefact rankles.|[[Griphook]] discussing his legacy|Harry Potter: Hogwarts Mystery}}
'''Urgruff the Unwary''' was a [[Great Britain|British]] [[Goblin]], who was deemed to be one of the finest [[Goblin-made ironwork|smiths]] in Goblin history.<ref name="HM6"/>

==Biography==
Urgruff boasted that he could make a perfect replica of a [[Dragon egg]] in solid [[gold]]. True to his word, he was indeed able to accomplish this feat, only for it to be stolen by a 'mother dragon' that mistook it for one of her own, torched his workshop and retrieved the priced treasure from the ashes of the smithy.<ref name="HM6"/>

At some point during the [[1989–1990 school year]] at [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]], [[Gringotts Wizarding Bank]] received intelligence suggesting this dragon had been captured and confined to a famous [[Romanian Dragon Sanctuary|Dragon Sanctuary]] in [[Romania]], and tasked one of their [[Curse-Breakers]], [[William Weasley|Bill Weasley]], with retrieving it, having even obtained a [[portkey]] to send him on his way.<ref name="HM6"/>

==Appearances==

{{Quote|Don't be sorry, my dear sir, for nothing could upset me today! Rejoice, for [[Tom Riddle|You-Know-Who]] has gone at last! Even [[Non-magic people|Muggle]]s like [[Vernon Dursley|yourself]] should be celebrating [[1 November|this happy, happy day]]!|The violet-cloaked wizard to Vernon Dursley|Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone}}

This '''violet-cloaked wizard''' was an old man [[Vernon Dursley]] ran into in [[November]] [[1981]]. Upon being knocked over by the latter, he stood back up and, told Vernon no apology was necessary as nothing could upset him that day and walked off, but not before giving Dursley a hug around the middle. He, among many other wizards, was in gleeful spirits that day as [[Tom Riddle|Lord Voldemort]] had been nearly vanquished (although everyone believed he was completely gone) thanks to the baby [[Harry Potter]].<ref name="PS1">{{PS|B|1}}</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*Given the similarity in their descriptions, it is possible that this individual is [[Filius Flitwick]]. Even though this scene takes place during the [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry|Hogwarts]] school year, [[Albus Dumbledore|two other]] [[Minerva McGonagall|Hogwarts professors]] and [[Rubeus Hagrid|one other staff member]] were known to be outside the school that day as well.
*It is also possible that this man is [[Dedalus Diggle]], who is described in some similar ways as well.

==Appearances==
*{{PS}}

{{Quote|And if wishes grew on trees, life would be a breeze. Please pester someone else!|Viridian's portrait, refusing to open to [[Harry Potter]]|Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (video game)}}

'''Professor Vindictus Viridian''' was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who was a [[potioneer]], author and [[Headmaster]] of [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]] in the early [[18th century|eighteenth century]].

==Biography==
===Lifetime===
Based on his portrait, Viridian was a [[potioneer]]. At some point in his life, he was named [[Headmaster]] of [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]].<ref name="WWHP">{{WWHP}} - see [[:File:Dumbledore's office portraits.jpg|this image]]</ref> Also during his lifetime, he published a famous book on [[dark charm]]s: ''[[Curses and Counter-Curses|Curses and Counter-Curses (Bewitch your Friends and Befuddle your Enemies with the Latest Revenges: Hair Loss, Jelly-Legs, Tongue-Tying and much, much more)]]''.<ref name="PS5"/> He also published the book ''[[How to Tame Tigers]]''.<ref name="csf">{{COS|F}} {{see image|File:HowtoTameTigers.jpg}}</ref>

===Post-mortem===
[[File:Dumbledore's office portraits.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Professor Viridian's portrait in the [[Headmaster's office]]]]
Professor Viridian died sometime in or prior to [[1994]].<ref name="DOD"/> Two [[Headmaster portraits|portraits]] of him hung at Hogwarts: one was painted in [[1703]]<ref>See [[:File:VindictusViridian3.jpg|this image]].</ref> and hung in the Headmaster's office along with the portraits of other Headmasters and Headmistresses,<ref name="WWHP"/> and the other hung in the [[Grand Staircase]].<ref name="OPg">{{OOTP|G}}</ref>

In the [[1995-1996 school year]], Viridian's portrait at the [[Grand Staircase]] was used to conceal the entrance to the [[Room of Rewards]]. He was frequently annoyed by all the hustle and bustle of the students' school life. In order to gain entry to the Room of Rewards, [[Hermione Granger]] threatened to convince [[Myrtle Warren]] to haunt the landing where the portrait hung. Disliking Myrtle, Viridian let [[Harry Potter]] and his friends through.<ref name="OPg"/>

==Magical abilities and skills==
[[File:VindictusViridian3.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Portrait of an older Vindictus Viridian]]
*'''[[Dark Arts]]''': Professor Viridian was highly proficient with [[curse]]s, [[hex]]es and [[jinx]]es, and wrote [[Curses and Counter-Curses|a book]] which included such [[dark charm]]s as the: [[Full Body-Bind Curse]], [[Jelly-Legs Curse]], [[Leg-Locker Curse]], [[Pimple Jinx]], [[Stickfast Hex]], [[Tickling Hex]], [[Tongue-Tying Curse]] and [[Hair Loss Curse]].<ref name="PS5">{{PS|B|5}}</ref>
*'''[[Potion]]s''': Professor Viridian was a highly accomplished and skilful [[Potioneer]], as evidenced by several portraits of him brewing various [[potion]]s.

==Etymology==
The name Vindictus is derived from the Latin ''vindicta'' ("revenge") and the surname Viridian from the Latin ''viridis'' ("green").

==Behind the scenes==
*{{HPLE}} confirms that his surname was misspelled "Veridian" in the [[Harry Potter (film series)|film series]].

'''Boris Vulchanov''' was a Bulgarian [[wizardkind|wizard]] and a [[Beater]] on the [[2014]] [[Bulgarian National Quidditch team]]. His father [[Pyotr Vulchanov]] played in the [[1994 Quidditch World Cup]] final.<ref name="PM">{{PM}} - [[BULGARIA VERSUS NEW ZEALAND]] (Archived)</ref>

==Biography==
Vulchanov was quoted in [[Ginevra Weasley|Ginny Potter]]'s article on the semi-final match between [[Bulgaria]] and [[Japan]], saying "''We've been underdogs all through this tournament. We have nothing to lose and everything to win. We'll leave everything out there.''" It was in this game that Vulchanov flew deliberately in front of a [[Bludger]] to protect his team's [[Seeker]] [[Viktor Krum]], who was in pursuit of the [[Golden Snitch|Snitch]]. Vulchanov was knocked out cold and fell from his broom, only to be saved by Japanese Seeker [[Noriko Sato]]. Krum, seeing Sato's temporary vulnerability and inability to compete for the Snitch, pulled up and waited for her instead of using this to his advantage. All three consequently received a standing ovation from the audience for their excellent display of sportsmanship, one no one watching would be likely to forget.

}}'''Professor Vulpus'''<ref name="HPLE">{{HPLE}} (''The Paintings of Hogwarts'')</ref> was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]]. It is unknown if he was a [[Muggle-born]], [[half-blood]] or [[Pure-blood|pure blood]].

==Biography==
===Lifetime===
Professor Vulpus was appointed as [[Headmaster]] of [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]] sometime before [[Armando Dippet]].

===Post-mortem===
After his death, his [[Headmaster portraits|portrait]] was hung in the [[Headmaster's office]] in order to give advice to the current Head.<ref>{{COS|F}} DVD (Disc 2 - ''Dumbledore's Office'')</ref>

==Etymology==
*The name ''Vulpus'' may come from ''[[wikipedia:Vulpes|Vulpes]]'', the Latin word for "fox".

==Appearances==
*{{COS|F}} {{Portrait}}
*{{WWHP}} {{Portrait}}

This '''[[Wizardkind|wizard]]''' was a waiter at the [[Leaky Cauldron]] pub in [[London]], assisting barman [[Tom]] in his duties by wandlessly and non-verbally collecting plates to be washed.<ref name="POAF">{{POA|F}}</ref>

==Physical appearance==
The waiter had brown hair and white skin, and wore a dark blue uniform.<ref name="POAF"/>

==Magical abilities and skills==
*'''[[Nonverbal spell|Nonverbal]] and [[Wandless magic]]''': This wizard could magically carry a large stack of plates without saying a single [[incantation]] and without the use of a [[wand]], which is highly advanced [[magic]].<ref name="POAF"/>

A host of '''waiters''' served food at the [[Wedding of William Weasley and Fleur Delacour|wedding]] of [[William Weasley|Bill Weasley]] and [[Fleur Delacour]] on [[1 August]], [[1997]] at [[the Burrow]].

==History==
They wore white robes and arrived at two o'clock; while guests were arriving, they sat with the [[Band at Bill Weasley and Fleur Delacour's wedding|band]] under a tree close to the main tent, smoking pipes. After the vows were completed and the reception began, the waiters filled the tent and carried silver trays of [[Pumpkin Juice|Pumpkin juice]], [[Butterbeer]], and [[Firewhisky]], others tottering piles of tarts and sandwiches.<ref name="DH8">{{DH|B|8}}</ref>

When the reception was [[Attack at the Burrow|attacked]] by [[Death Eaters]] that evening following the [[Fall of the Ministry of Magic|fall]] of the [[British Ministry of Magic|Ministry of Magic]], the waiters presumably fled, along with most of the guests.<ref name="DH9">{{DH|B|9}}</ref>

==Appearances==
*{{DH}} {{1st}}

'''Mr Warbeck''' was a [[Wales|Welsh]] [[wizardkind|wizard]] who worked as a minor functionary in the [[Muggle Liaison Office]] in the early [[20th century]].<ref name="Pottermore" />

He met his [[Celestina Warbeck's mother|wife]], a [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] actress, when she was attacked by a [[Lethifold]] which had disguised itself as a stage curtain.<ref name="Pottermore" /> The couple had at least one child, [[Celestina Warbeck|Celestina]], who was born [[18 August]]<ref name="Pottermore" /> [[1917]].<ref name="chocolatefrog">[[Chocolate Frog Card|Famous Wizard Card]] ([[Celestina Warbeck]])</ref>

Celestina proved to have an exceptional voice at a young age. She grew up to become an internationally famous wizarding singer.<ref name="Pottermore" />

==Appearances==
*{{PM}} {{1st mention}}
*{{WW}} {{Mention}}

'''Irving Warble''' was a [[wizardkind|wizarding]] composer. He married [[Celestina Warbeck]] after she left her [[Celestina Warbeck's second husband|second husband]] to be with him.<ref name="Pottermore" />

==Etymology==
*Irving is a [[Scotland|Scottish]] surname, though it is sometimes used as a first name as well. The name is derived from the {{wplink|River Irvine}}. [[Wikipedia:Irving Berlin|Irving Berlin]] is considered one of the greatest American songwriters; his most popular popular songs include such musical standards as ''[[Wikipedia:Alexander's Ragtime Band|Alexander's Ragtime Band]]'', ''[[Wikipedia:White Christmas (song)|White Christmas]]'', ''[[Wikipedia:Happy Holiday (song)|Happy Holidays]]'', ''[[Wikipedia:Cheek to Cheek|Cheek to Cheek]]'', ''[[Wikipedia:Let's Face the Music and Dance|Let's Face the Music and Dance]]'' and ''[[Wikipedia:Oh! How I Hate to Get Up in the Morning|Oh! How I Hate to Get Up in the Morning]]''.
*Warble is an English verb meaning "to sing in a high or shaky voice" and is a word often associated with the singing of birds.

==Appearances==
*{{PM}} {{Mention}}
*{{WW}} {{Mention}}

==Notes and references==

{{Quote|Come on, Rubeus. The dead girl's parents will be here tomorrow. The least Hogwarts can do is make sure that the thing that killed their daughter is slaughtered...|[[Tom Riddle]] falsely pins Myrtle's death on [[Aragog]]|Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets}}

'''Mr Warren''' was a [[Non-magic people|Muggle]]<ref>{{COS|B|12}}</ref> and the father of [[Muggle-born]] [[Wizardkind|witch]] [[Myrtle Warren|Myrtle Elizabeth Warren]], who attended [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]], and was killed by a [[Salazar Slytherin's Basilisk|Basilisk]] there on [[13 June]], [[1943]]. He planned to go to the school with his [[Myrtle Warren's mother|wife]] soon after this tragedy occurred.<ref>{{COS|B|13}}</ref>

His daughter's [[ghost]], known as Moaning Myrtle, resided in the [[Hogwarts Castle|girls' bathroom]] at [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry|Hogwarts]].

==Behind the scenes==
*According to [[Tom Riddle]], Myrtle's parents would get to [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry|Hogwarts]] some time after their daughter's death. However, it's unknown if this happened as Hogwarts can't be seen by Muggles. However it is likely that these spells were temporarily removed to allow them to collect their child's body, or an employee of Hogwarts escorted them in order to make the castle visible.

==Appearances==

An '''unknown man''' was a [[Muggle]] and the father of two daughters, [[Ivy Warrington|Ivy]] and [[Winifred Warrington]]. At least one daughter, Ivy was a [[Wizardkind|witch]].<ref name="MA" />

During her childhood, Ivy accidentally caused Winifred to vanish, and their grandmother put a [[Memory Charm]] on her so she would forget what she did to her, but it caused her to completely forget Winifred. Ivy later started attending [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]].<ref name="MA" />

{{Quote|The wealthy man who owned the Riddle House these days neither lived there nor put it to any use; they said in the village that he kept it for "tax reasons", though nobody was very clear what these might be. The wealthy owner continued to pay Frank to do the gardening, however.|Owner of the [[Riddle House]]|Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire}}
This '''individual''' (fl. [[1994]]) was a wealthy [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] man, who owned the [[Riddle House]] in the [[1990s]].<ref name="GOF1"/>

He did not live in it, nor put it to any use, although he still paid [[Frank Bryce]] to do the gardening before his death in [[1994]]. Nobody in [[Little Hangleton]] seemed to know why he kept the house, although it was said it was for "''tax reasons"''.<ref name="GOF1">{{GOF|B|1}}</ref>

{{Quote|Wandering through the crowd so as to escape a drunken uncle of Ron’s who seemed unsure whether or not Harry was his son...|This uncle at [[Wedding of William Weasley and Fleur Delacour|Bill and Fleur's wedding]]|{{DH}}}}

This '''uncle''' of the [[Weasley family|Weasley children]] got drunk at the [[Wedding of William Weasley and Fleur Delacour|wedding]] of [[William Weasley|Bill Weasley]] and [[Fleur Delacour]] on [[1 August]], [[1997]]. He spent part of the wedding wondering whether or not [[Harry Potter]], who was disguised as a red-haired [[Weasley family|Weasley]] cousin, was his son.<ref>{{DH}}: "Wandering through the crowd so as to escape a drunken uncle of Ron’s who seemed unsure whether or not Harry was his son..." (Ch. 8)</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*As it is known that [[Arthur Weasley]] had [[Arthur Weasley's brothers|two brothers]] and no sisters,<ref name="JKR">"[http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/extrastuff_view.cfm?id=7 Extra Stuff: The Weasley Family]" at {{JKRS}}</ref> it is widely assumed that the unnamed "uncle of Ron's" mentioned in {{DH}} is one of [[Arthur Weasley|Arthur]]'s brothers, and thus a Weasley. However, since it is unknown whether [[Gideon Prewett|Gideon]] and [[Fabian Prewett]] were [[Molly Weasley]]'s only siblings, it is possible the unnamed uncle was another brother of [[Molly Weasley|Molly]] or the husband of her sister.

==Appearances==
*{{DH}} {{Mention}}

{{Dialogue a-b|[[Harry Potter]]|Are all your [[Weasley family|family]] [[Wizardkind|wizards]]?|[[Ronald Weasley|Ron Weasley]]|Er — yes, I think so. I think Mum's got a second cousin who's an accountant, but we never talk about him.|Ron Weasley mentioning this individual|Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone}}
A male '''second cousin''' of [[Molly Weasley]] (née [[Prewett family|Prewett]]) became an accountant and/or a stockbroker in the [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] world.<ref name="PS6">{{PS|B|6}}</ref><ref name="mafalda">"[http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/extrastuff_view.cfm?id=3 Mafalda (Goblet of Fire)]" at [http://www.jkrowling.com J.K. Rowling Official Site] (archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20080317115534/http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/extrastuff_view.cfm?id=3 here] via the Internet Archive's Wayback Machine)</ref> [[Ronald Weasley|Ron Weasley]] told [[Harry Potter]] that this man was never spoken of in the [[Weasley family|Weasley household]].<ref name="PS6" />

==Behind the scenes==
*[[J. K. Rowling]] revealed on her website that in an early draft of {{GOF}}, this character was married to a [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] [[Mafalda's mother|woman]], and, against all expectation, had fathered a daughter who was a [[Wizardkind|witch]], [[Mafalda]]. Although he had previously been rude to [[Arthur Weasley|Mr]] and [[Molly Weasley|Mrs Weasley]], he and his wife were to have sought the Weasley family's help in introducing Mafalda to wizarding culture when they learned that she would be attending [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry|Hogwarts]].
*The information on Rowling's website states that Molly's second cousin was a stockbroker.<ref name="mafalda" /> This conflicts with Ron Weasley's statement in ''[[Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone|Philosopher's Stone]]'' that he was an accountant.<ref name="PS6" /> However, it is possible that Ron, being unfamiliar with the Muggle world, was merely incorrect.

==Appearances==
*{{PS}} {{1st Mention}}
*{{JKRS}} {{Mention}}

'''Fred Weasley''' (b. [[2000s]]) was the oldest child of [[George Weasley|George]] and [[Angelina Johnson|Angelina Weasley]] {{Comment|née Johnson}}. He was named in memory of his uncle [[Fred Weasley]], who was killed during the [[Battle of Hogwarts]]. He had a younger sister named [[Roxanne Weasley|Roxanne]].<ref name="story">[http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/books/article3105517.ece Times Online - The Unwritten Story of Harry's Friends and Their Children]</ref>

Fred attended the [[2014 Quidditch World Cup]] with his family.<ref name="PM">{{PM}}</ref>

}}'''Alec Webb''' was a [[Great Britain|British]] [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] concert director. He directed a performance of [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s ''[[Sinfonia Concertanti]]'' that was held at [[St. Mary's Church Hall]] at 7:30 in the evening on Sunday [[7 May]] in a year prior to [[1997]], which featured [[Emanuel Hurwitz]] on [[violin]], [[Kay Hurwitz]] on [[viola]], and the [[Dollis Chamber Ensemble]].<ref name="hple">{{HPLE|G}} {{see image|File:Emanuel&KayHurwitzConcertPoster.jpg}}</ref> [[Hermione Granger]] had a poster for this concert stuck up on the bulletin board in [[Hermione Granger's bedroom|her bedroom]] in the [[Granger family]]'s [[Grangers' house|house]].<ref name="hple" /><ref name="dhp1">{{DH|F1}}</ref>

}}'''Hadrian Whittle''' was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]], [[Herbologist]] and the author of ''[[Magical Water Plants of the Highland Lochs]]''.<ref>[http://www.pottermania.jp/Gallery/2005Sekaiten/pages/MatsudoSekaiten001.htm Book prop image on Pottermania.jp]</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*This character may have been named after [http://hadriangardendesign.com/ Hadrian Whittle], a British garden designer who has worked with [http://www.filmscapes.co.uk/ Filmscapes],<ref>[http://hadriangardendesign.com/data/1_1.htm About page on HadrianGardenDesign.com]</ref> a company which did landscaping work for the first five ''Harry Potter'' [[Harry Potter (film series)|films]].<ref>[http://www.filmscapes.co.uk/credits.php Credits list on Filmscapes.co.uk]</ref>
*Whittle possibly wrote [[Magical Mediterranean Water-Plants and Their Properties|Magical Water Plants of the Mediterranean]] after the popular [[Magical Water Plants of the Highland Lochs]].

==Etymology==
The name "Hadrian" comes from the Roman cognomen Hadrianus, which meant "from Hadria" in Latin. Hadria was a town in northern Italy (it gave its name to the Adriatic Sea). A famous bearer of the name was Publius Aelius Hadrianus, better known as Hadrian, a 2nd-century Roman emperor who built a wall across northern Britain.

==Appearances==
*{{GOF|F}} {{1st Mention}}

{{Quote|Dear Buckley, No, the Ministry of Magic would not turn a blind eye if you turn your nieces and nephews into blood-sucking ferrets. We will arrest you and you will probably find yourself in Azkaban. I advise you to call a halt to this feud before somebody gets hurt. In the meantime, contact the Office for the Removal of Curses, Jinxes and Hexes, who will take care of both the broomstick and your brother.|Dempster Wiggleswade's reply on the Problem Page of the Daily Prophet.|Daily Prophet Newsletters}}


'''Dempster Wiggleswade''' was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who worked for the [[Department of Magical Law Enforcement]].<ref name="newsletters">''[[The Daily Prophet (real-world)|Daily Prophet Newsletters]]''</ref>

He also wrote for the ''[[Daily Prophet]]'', using his legal expertise to answer some of the questions submitted to the problem page, which also featured responses from [[Grizel Hurtz]], [[Zamira Gulch]], and [[Helbert Spleen]]. He strongly advised [[Buckley Cooper]] not to take revenge on his brother by turning his children into [[vampire]] [[ferret]]s.<ref name="newsletters" />

Following the return of [[Tom Riddle|Lord Voldemort]], he answered security questions from ''Daily Prophet'' readers.<ref name="hple">{{HPLE}}, see [[:File:Daily Prophet - Dark Times Ahead.jpg|this image]]</ref>

'''Winston''' was the uncle of a [[Winston's niece|female Hogwarts student]]. He once had a [[curse]] placed on him and never could get rid of it.<ref>{{PS|G}} - GBC version</ref>

==Etymology==
The name "Winston" is from a surname derived from an English place name, which was in turn derived from the Old English given name Wynnstan meaning "joy stone". A famous bearer was Winston Churchill (1874-1965), the British [[Prime Minister]] during World War II. This name was also borne by the fictional Winston Smith, the protagonist in [[George Orwell]]'s 1949 novel ''1984''.

'''Wladyslaw Wolfke''' (pl. Władysław Wroński) was a Polish [[wizardkind|wizard]] who played as the [[Seeker]] for the [[2014]] [[Polish National Quidditch team]]. He played in the seventh round match of the [[2014 Quidditch World Cup|427th Quidditch World Cup]], against [[Japanese National Quidditch team|Japan]]. Wolfke was described as "a daring and graceful flier" by [[Ginevra Weasley|Ginny Potter]]. Wolfke was unlucky enough to miss the [[Golden Snitch|Snitch]] early in the game, and was only narrowly beaten to it by [[Japanese National Quidditch team|Japanese]] Seeker [[Noriko Sato]] in the 59th minute.<ref name="PM">{{PM}} - [[JAPAN VERSUS POLAND|JAPAN_VERSUS_POLAND]] (Archived)</ref>

'''Jamie Wolpert''' was a [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] journalist who, in the summer of [[1996]], wrote the front-page article about the collapse of the [[Millennium Bridge]] for ''[[The Guardian]]''.<ref name="HPLE">{{HPLE|G}} (see [[:File:TheGuardian.png|this image]])</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*This character was named after [[Jamie Wolpert]], who worked behind-the-scenes as an assistant to [[David Yates]] on ''[[Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film)|Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix]]'' and ''[[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)|Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince]]'', and as a book consultant on {{DH|F1}} and ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2|Part 2]]''. He also had a cameo as a [[Unidentified newspaper vendor|''Daily Prophet'' newspaper vendor]] at the [[British Ministry of Magic|Ministry of Magic]] in ''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix''.<ref>"[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1660828/ Jamie Wolpert]" on IMDb</ref>

{{Quote|All right, darling? Fancy a drink? Ditch ginger and come and have a pint!|One of the men shouting to [[Hermione Granger]]|Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows}}

A group of [[Non-magic people|Muggle]] '''workmen''' were out drinking at pubs on [[Tottenham Court Road]] on the night of [[1 August]], [[1997]]. They spotted [[Harry Potter]], [[Ronald Weasley|Ron Weasley]], and [[Hermione Granger]] that night, just after the trio [[Apparition|Disapparated]] from [[the Burrow]] after the [[Death Eaters]] [[Fall of the Ministry of Magic|took over]] the [[British Ministry of Magic|Ministry of Magic]]. The men wolf-whistled at Hermione, and one drunkenly asked her to go get a drink with him. She ignored him, and entered a [[Luchino Caffe|café]] with Harry and Ron.

==Behind the scenes==
*After the trio unwittingly triggered the [[Taboo|Taboo curse]] on [[Tom Riddle|Lord Voldemort]]'s name, they were tracked by Death Eaters [[Antonin Dolohov]] and [[Thorfinn Rowle]], who disguised themselves as workmen and followed Harry, Ron, and Hermione into the café, where a brief [[Luchino Caffe Duel|skirmish]] ensued. It is possible that they incapacitated or killed the drunk workers in order to obtain the disguises, a theory which is supported by the detail of their existence being added at all.<ref>{{DH|B|9}}</ref>

==Appearances==
*{{DH}} {{1st}}

'''Augustus Worme''' was a [[Wizardkind|wizard]] who worked for the publisher [[Obscurus Books]]. In [[1918]], he commissioned a young [[Newton Scamander|Newt Scamander]] to write {{FB}}. The first edition of the book was published in [[1927]], and was a world-wide bestseller.<ref>{{FB|R}}</ref>

==Etymology==
The name "Augustus" means "great" or "venerable", derived from Latin augere "to increase". Augustus was the title given to Octavian, the first Roman emperor. He was the adopted son of Julius Caesar who rose to power through a combination of military skill and political prowess. This was also the name of three kings of Poland.

==Biography==
On [[6 December]] [[1926]], he attended an emergency meeting at the [[Pentagram Office]] to discuss the [[magic]]al disturbances in [[New York]], inquiring if [[Newton Scamander|Newt Scamander]] was his brother [[Theseus Scamander|Theseus]] when [[Hector Podmore]] addressed him by his surname.<ref>{{FB|S|60}}</ref>

==Behind the scenes==
*Momolu Wotorson was portrayed by [[Christian Dixon]] in ''[[Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)|Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them]]''.<ref>{{IMDb|nm3956045|Christian Dixon}}</ref>
*His attire is notably similar to that of [[Auror]] [[Kingsley Shacklebolt]], suggesting a cultural similarity between the two.
